information_requirement: Is an adversary using a non-standard or custom encrypted channel for command and control on our managed mobile devices? (PIR)

evidence.description: Mobile device network traffic exhibits characteristics of non-standard encryption or communicates with unusual endpoints over encrypted channels, deviating from baseline application behavior.
evidence.nai: Corporate Wi-Fi network gateways and VPN termination points.
evidence.action: From network data (Zeek logs, Mobile EDR/MDM logs) sourced from Wi-Fi gateways and VPN endpoints, establish a baseline of typical encrypted communication for corporate mobile devices. For each device, profile common TLS/SSL certificate attributes (issuer, subject) and JA3/JA3S hashes found in Zeek ssl.log. Use descriptive statistics to identify the most frequent values associated with legitimate business applications. Actively hunt for outliers, such as a high prevalence of self-signed certificates, certificates with nonsensical subject names, or JA3/JA3S hashes that do not match any known legitimate application in the environment. For identified suspicious connections, analyze connection metadata in Zeek conn.log to assess patterns (e.g., long-lived connections with regular 'heartbeat' traffic, high data volume to low-reputation IPs). A combination of an anomalous JA3 hash, a self-signed certificate, and traffic to a newly registered domain would strongly indicate a malicious encrypted channel.
